DIV2.P: Prof. Holthausen, in Anglia XVIII, 293-331, reprints two medical treatises preserved in a Stockholm manuscript which was first printed by G. Stephens in 1844 in the 30th volume of Archaeologia. The same poems are found in the Add. Ms. 17,866 in the British Museum, fol. 5a-21b, but in a text so different that it would be impossible to print merely a list of variants. The order of the poems is just reversed in the Add. Ms. from that in the Stockholm Ms., the prescriptions following the medico-botanical poem. I have numbered the two as one, as they occur in the Ms.

It is a beautiful manuscript, written on parchment with great care. There is practically no attempt at adornment, aside from the rubrications. The catalogue says it belongs to the fourteenth century, and on the inside leaf is written: 'This M. S. seems to belong to the time of the first or second Edward', i. e. 1272-1327. This, however seems at least one hundred fifty years too early. It shows many traces of northern dialect, but is not consistent.

Dragaunce . and serpentyne same.

Off Genciana & baldemonye & of is los

In medewes & wodes wyde

Ambiger exstupat tussim pectus stomachum

wt in thre dayes & thre nyght.

To make it of gode reles & stale.
And sourhede of ale it wil abate.
Als lange as sauge may kepe his state.
Ȝit telles maister macrobius.
A vers of sauge & says þus
Cur moritur homo dum salgia crescit in orto.
For defaute whi dies þe mane.
þt sauge & mynte to helpe hane.
Lat hyme take sauge of þe ȝerde
For no wenyme hym thare be ferde.
To etyn it bothe rype & grene.
His body shal it make ful clene.
Who so it etes & drynkes I say.
Till keynde dede euel come shal he nouȝt dey
Contra vim mortis non est medicamen in ortis.
Rewe is gode to done in ale.
To make it both clere & stale.
The water of rewe is gode for syght.
This water schal be mayde in a vrinalle.
And take water of rose wt alle.
And other wateres many þer to.
Of seladyne & veruayne al so.
Rewe wil distroye venyme.
Wt outen mannes body & wt Inne.
And als a pike it makith hyme clene.
Wt Inne and oute alle be dene.
A tode þt is a venemus thynge.
He dryues a way thorow is waxynge.
Ȝet is rewe a souerayne bote.
To sette a boute a sauge rote.
It shal do it waxe wele & fyne
And kepe it fro alle manere of venyme.
Ȝit tellith þe maister in his rymynge.
That rewe is a ful denteyth thynge.
Mangetz rew beueitz rew & vos ganer a la vewe.
Mettz rew a la vewe & vos touder a le vew.
This is to say on englysshe
That here is wretyne on frenshe.
Ete rewe & drynke rew day & nyght.
And it wille make þe ful gode syght.
And do lay rewe vnto thi sight.
And it shal a peire sone in plyght.
Who so shal wyrke wt gres to sene.
War & wyse he moste bene.
But he hym knawe in gres welle.
He schal for lese his werk ilke dele.
Fenkill. says maister macrobius.
Is a gres ful precious.
Gode is the gres so is the rote.
To dyuerse medecynes he may do bote.
The seide is gode fastande to ete.
And also in drage after mete.
For wicked humours and bolnynge.
For wynd & many a nother thynge.
Als telles the maister milde of mode.
The water of þe fenkell is ful gode.
For to clarefye mannys syght.
If it be stilled and made oryght
And do þer to water of roset.
For mannys syght þe water is bote.
Shire water is gode al so
Off rewe & of veruayne to take þer to.
Whan þei ere al to geder done.
þai helpe mannys sight redy & sone.
And celydyne ȝit may men take.
For he is nought for to for sake.
Fenkyll in potage and in mete.
It (sic) ful gode þer in to ete.
like grene it be corfyn small.
In what mete so men ete it schall
In what drynke so men shall it drynke
It is gode for þe pose & þe host kynke
It is best for mannes syght.
Namlyke if it be vsed aryght.
Uiolet . I tell in my langage.
Is gode to do in potage
To make iowtes in someres tyde.
When þe leues ere brode or wyde.
In plaisters & woundes is comfortatife.
Wt other gres full sanatife.
And of is flours is comfortabille.
Wt ole roset ful medicinabille.
The oyle of is fair flours.
Distroyes in man alle wyked humours.
Wher fore I preise it for prise.
For in boke comaunded it is.
The scharpe burre . who so will take.
þer wt maisteryes he make.

For he waxes hy in someres dele
Thair wt men may wel witen & sene.

lat take þat burr and caste in fyer.
Whenne it brennes clere and schire.

That holdes þem maydons & are none.

Sic vt cocta simul sit mel ficus quoque sicca

Off Columbyne . I wele ȝow telle

Fumiter is a gres I say.
That sprynges in þe mounthe of may.
In felde & toun ȝerd & gate.
Ther land is fatte & in gode state.
Of dunhed rede he beres a floure.
Fair to syght is hys coloure.
Men drynke it oft in somere and may.
For þe feueres þt comes ilke day.
And als for þe feuere terciane.
And also for þe feuere quartane.
It dryues away all puretours
And distroies veneme & wycked humours.
She þt drynkes fumiter & þe stoncrope.

wt þe forthe parte succer or ony iij in þe seuenyght.

LG.HEAD: For the hede werke.
LG.L: Iff a man or womman more or lesse
In his hede haue grett seiknesse.
Or eny greuaunce or eny werkynge.
Aueroyne he take wt outen lettynge.
That is called sothernewode also
And hony & aysell tempere þer to.
And þis drynke fastande lat hym drynke.
And is hedwarke a way schal synke
Take aysell and pelyal ryall.
And camamylle do seth wt alle.
And wt þe lous a noynte þe nostrell welle.
And make a plaistre of þt other dele.
And do it in a gode gret clothe.
And wynde þt hed þer wt aboute.
Also it is gode for þe hede ake.
Ten kyrneel of peper for to take.
And grynd it wt aysell amange.
And drynke it or bynde to þe thonewange.
Late take vnces of betayne.
And of harhone also mane.
And vij vnces of pelyall riall.
And bray þem all to gedere small.
And lete it stande two dayes or thre.
Tille it full whit houe þer on to be.
And alle þes gresse lat take þanne.
And fry wt oyle de olyue in a panne.
A quartrione of virgine waxe þu take.
And fraunce ensens þer wt nessch to make.
And þes gres alle do þer to.
And alle to geder lete wele play so.
And if it be daungerus and lothe.
Late clense it wel thorow a cloth.
And when it is wrongen wel & clene.
Rub wele þe hede þer wt be dene.
And alle þe hede warke & þe ake
In lytill throwe a way schal slake.

And late it welle well ouere þe fire.
And take a dysshfull of whete branne
And als it boyles lat caste þer Inne
Take an handful of rose floures.
And cast þer in off rede coloures.
And menge al to geder saunz de lay
Als wel as euere þu may.

LG.HEAD: For sore eyen. A gode medsyn.
LG.L: Take rose and rewe and redd fenkele.
And celadyne do grynd þem welle.
In somere þu schal þes gres take.
And stilled water of þem do make.
þis thyng is proued for þe syght.
To clere þe eyen & make þem bryght.
To gretande eyen and to watery.
Take rewe and aysell & meng wt hony.
And stamp al to geder be dene.
And wrynge it out þorw a cloth clene.
And þis drynke schal sone a none.
Slake þe water tere ilkone.
Lat geder a hepe of redd snayles.
þt crepe aboute in rayn & hayles.
And seith þem in welle water wele.
And gader of þe gres ilke dele.
And grese þin eyen wel wt alle.
And sone þi syght amende it schal.
A medcyne ȝit for eyen bote.
Take þe Ious of fenkyll rote.
And droppe it in þi eyen ewen & morwe.
The payne schal slake & þe sorwe.
Ious of betayne wt hony is gode.
To dryue fro the eyen all ille blode.
This ys thynge þt proued is.
It cleres þi eyen well Iwys.
For defe hede & dul herynge.
I fynde wretyn dyuerse thynge.
To the ere þt ill may here.
This is a medcyne gode & clere.
Take a porcion aff bores vreyne.
And meng wt hony clere & fyne.
And in þe ere lat be caste.
The heryng shal amende in haste.
If in þi ere be any foul thyng.
Or filthe þt lettes þi heryng.

And helpe þi herynge in a thrawe.
Also þu take in someres seson.
A gres is called pedelyon.
Take þe Ious and an hard ay.
And do þe schelle clene away.
Whenne þei ere wrongen & in þe ere done.
þe heryng schal amende sone
The Ious off betayne ȝit is beste.
To stampe it welle & lat it reste.
And when it is clere & thyne.
wt oyle let do the ere wt Inne.
And thorew þe helpe of heuen kynge.
It shal sone helpe þi herynge.
A man þt feles in his ere
Als hornes blew or thunder wer.
Lat hym brenne a braunche of esche.
And take þe water þt rennes oute nesche.
And Ious of Iubarbe take also.
And also mekell as of þes two.
And a porcion of greys of an ele.
And meng þem al to geder wele.
And lat it in hys ere be done.
His heryng shal amende ful sone.
Take a nonyon gode & harde.
And make a hole in þe mydwarde.
And pour in hony clere & schire.
And roste it to geder wele in þe fire.
And when it is rosted wel þorw oute.
Lat it be wrongen thorow a cloute.
And poure it in thi ere at euen.
And þt ille schal nothyn greuen.

LG.HEAD: For wormes in manes ere.
LG.L: Iff any worme be waxen grylle.
In mannes ere & greue hym ille.
The ious of wodebynde in ilke sessonne.
Schal hote in his ere be done.
And al þe wormes for soithe anone.
The boyke says it schal þem slone.
alle þe payne and þe damage.
þis hote Ious schal do aswage
And also ment after grynd it small
And hot red wyen þu do wt alle
And pour in þi ere bothe be dene.
It slos þe worme þi ere makes clene.
Sumtyme defhed will be tyde.
If a man haue eres wyde.
Pureter wil þer in waxe thyke.
And make þe heryng defe & wyke.
And þane is gode sone anone.
Wt a respone do it oute agone.
And also def hede falles some stounde.
Boith of betyng And of wounde.
And of postemes And of blode.
þis knowes wel leches þt bene gode.
þerfore medecynes ere gode and clene.
Be fore I haue tolde ȝow alle be dene.

LG.HEAD: For laynge of speche in seknes.
LG.L: If a man for seknes haue layde speche.
Gode medecynes I wil hyme teche.
Take violet and pelyal ryall.
And grynd þaem to gedere small.
And lat hym drynke þe Ious ful thynne
And pour þer of in his eres wt Inne.
And als þe maister recordes & sayne.
He schal take his speche agayne.

LG.HEAD: For wounde in mannes hede.
LG.L: If a man be woundyt ille
In is hede and dos hym grill.
Betayne and veruayne . þer to he take.
Wt swynes grese a plaistre make.
And byndyt to þe wounde faste.
It schal be hole sone in haste.
For þe fallande goute is wretyn þis boute.
Of louache þu schal take þe rote.
Wasch it and writ þer on þus.
Ihc † cristus † dominus.
But the writere moste in clene lyf be.
And say pater noster and aues thre.
And sithen bynde it in a speke.
And hong aboute þe seke mannes neke.
And after þt it be hanged þore.
The sekenesse he schal haue no more.

LG.HEAD: For þe goute a gode medecyne.
LG.L: Tak þe Ious of Iubarbe ful an ay.
And also mekil ayssel thenne as way
loke þt þe aysell be scharpe & soure
And meng it wt a porcion of barly flour.
On a flaxen cloute sprede it clene.
And bynde it þer þe goute is most sene.

LG.HEAD: For þe goute þt is festered,
LG.L: Take oyle Iubarbe & arlement.
That al to geder be tempered & blent.
This plaister layde on a flaxon cloute.
Bynd þe sore fester well a boute.
If þer be in hole or wounde.
Pour þer in þe Ious or it be bounde.
Als gode leches all sayne.
Men schal þer to nouȝt ellys layne.

LG.HEAD: For bolnyng of armes.
LG.L: Iff mannes armes be bolnede grete.
Take shepyn talwe and floure of qwete.
And Ius of ache þu do þer to.
And seith them wele to geder so.
Hote als it comes out of þe panne.
Late make a plaister þer of þanne.
And bynd it on þe armes faste.
And þe bolnynge schal swage in haste.

LG.HEAD: For bolnyng þt comyth of wenym.
LG.L: In cas rankelynge be falle of venyme.
Als erane or pode or oþer serpyne.
Tak barly flour and aysell or wyne.
And hony menged wt sede of lyne.
And well þem to geder euerylkone.
Than wil þis plaister all ranclyng slone.

LG.HEAD: ffor bolnyng of pappes.
LG.L: Whoso of pappes haue gret bolnyng.
Make þis plaistere for eny thynge
Take doues donge & hony wel grounde.
And tempere þer wt wax virgine þt stounde.
Lat lay þis plaistere þer apone.
The bolnyng schal a way gone.

LG.HEAD: For to swage bolnyng.
LG.L: A rancle wel for to swage.
On man of ȝougtht or of gret age.
Tak frankensence & whete mele.
And Ious of walworte & of morele.
And Ious of ache schal þer to gone.
Herbe benet & hemeloke bothe is one.
And bray þem wele in swynes gress.
And make a plaister of gode relases.
þis plaister þu lay to rankyll a none
And alle þe rankylle schal ouer gone.
And if it drye þis maister sayne.
It may be chaufede and layde agayne
Take a blew cloute þt is fyne.
And boyle it well wt salt in wyne.
And lay it be þe renkille alday.
And þe rankelynge schal swage away.

LG.HEAD: For bolnyng of knees.
LG.L: Iff þi knees be bolnede grete.
þu take þe faire flour of whete.
And boile it in water till yt drye be.
And in a cloute lay till þi kne.

LG.HEAD: For bolnynge of schankes.
LG.L: Take walworte rotes stif & starke.
Sethe well in water pyle of þe barke.
And in a morter grynde þem smale.
And stampe shepes talwe þer wt alle.
And lay it hote in a cloute.
And bynd þe bolnynge þer wt aboute.

LG.HEAD: For bolnyng of the feet.
LG.L: Plantayne & pulyall shal wel be grounde
wt myes of whit brede & ache a stounde.
And menge wt aysell & swynes grese
Bene to bolnynge fete ful gode relese.
For bolnyng of genitales of a man.
a fair medecyn tell I can.
Bothe for olde & for ȝonge.
And ale manere of brynnynge
Leues of lorer and rewe þu take.
And small þu do þem bryse & make.
Take there handfull of þe tone.
And of þe tother als mekill a none.
And make a plaister þer of ful clene.
About þe genytales þu bynde be dene.
And if þis will þe helpe nought.
Anoþer medecyne schal be wrought.
Tak leues of rede docke.
The tenderonnes in myddes a way þu knocke.
Seth þem in wyne hole in panne.
And lay þem aboute þe ballokes þanne.
Also take garlyk & comyne.
wt ache and bennes sothene in wyne.
And bynd a boute þe ballokes faste.
And þe bolnyng shal swage in haste.

LG.HEAD: For bolnyng of þe virge.
LG.L: The maister telles if þe virge be brent.
Als man of womman may so be schent.
Thorw þt woman may be his bote.
Of wham his sekenes be gan þe rote.
The beste medecyne þt I can telle.
Hyme be houes to water yn at hir well.
And if he may nought þt womman take.
Another medecyn moste hym make.
Tak þan þe sede of lyne.
And boile it in milke and wyne.
Do yt hot in a letheryne hodkyne.
And lat is virge hange so þer Inne.
When it is colde het it agayne.
Bothe morwen and ewyn þer to it layne.
Ȝet þer is a gode medecyne.
For brennynge of þe virge and for þe pyne.
Tak sauge and malwes & seth in bryne.
And þen tak comyn & cast þer Inne.
And mele of benes þu take also.
A lytill whit of eyren lat do þer to.
And Ious of ache & grese of swyne.
wt hony melled to geder þer Inne.
And when þis plaistere is made a fyne.
Wel warme bynd it to þe virge wt lyne.

LG.HEAD: For þe hote and þe colde dropcy.
LG.L: Take a handfull of ȝonge elleryne spritils
Scrape of þe ouerest wt a twytele.
And boile it þanne wel and fyne.
In a galon of ale or in red wyne.
And wt centory lat it sethe wele.
Tylle it be sothen to þe half dele.
Gyf hym to drynke ewen & morwe.
And it shal sone slak his sorwe.
Here I haue told ȝow as I canne.
For þe dropcy to man or womman.

LG.HEAD: For bledyng atte þe nose.
LG.L: A man þt wille helpe a noþer at nede.
And sees hym at his nose blede.
Tak peruynke a gres ful couth.
Be twyx his teith halde in is mouth.
In alle þe tyme þat it be thore.
For sothe he schal blede no more.

LG.HEAD: For to knowe the festers.
LG.L: Als leches in bokes fynde & sene.
Two manere of festeres for soth þer bene.
The tone is colde and gnawande.
The toþer is hote and ay byrnande.
þe colde has a strayt hole & ful noyous.
The hote a wyde hole & more perilous.
Diuerse medecynes for þem I finde.
For þei ere nought bothe of o kynde.
The colde fester schal be heled wt hete
And colde schal þe hote bete.
And comunly so schal befalle.
Of medecynes in leche craft alle.

LG.HEAD: ffor þe brennande fester.
LG.L: Off hony & ryeflour bake a kake.
So hard als men it may make.
Lay on þe hole þt festerd is sore.
When it is nesche a nother lay þore.
And so it schal hele þis maister say.
Nothyng elles þer to þu lay.

LG.HEAD: For þe colde festere.
LG.L: Ious of launcile for sothe I say
wt þe white of ayeren tway
And a porcion of rye mele.
And lett þem welle to geder wele.
And on þe festere þu it lay.
Till by it self it falle away.
And make a newe sone þu do.
Till it be hole lay it þer to.

LG.HEAD: For þe cankere.
LG.L: Tak aporcion of bakoune lene.
And lat it brenne in pouder clene.
Do wasch it wele stale anone.
And cast þis pouder þer apone.

LG.HEAD: Pelotes for woundes.
LG.L: Iff a wounde be holl or depe.
Ther off a leche most tak gode kepe
Tak thamur smal consoude & plantayne.
Bugyle avance and lancelayne.
Pympernoll ȝarow & confery fyne.
And sethe þem togeder in gode red wynne.
The wounded man schal drynke it hot at euen.
and cold at morwe it schal nought greuyn.
It schal purge & clense þe wounde.
And make þe man bothe hole & sounde.

LG.HEAD: For a wounde in a mannes hed.
LG.L: Iff þu haue in þi hed a wounde.
Tak betayne wher it may be founde.
Meng it wt grece of a swyne.
Non other salue thar come þer Inne.
Tak salt grece of a swynn & veruayne.
Wil make a wounde hole agayne.

LG.HEAD: For to drawe agayn þe hyde of a wounde.
LG.L: Ther is a gres softe as sylke.
When it is brokyn Ious like is milk.
A plaister þer of þes leches sayne.
The hyde to geder it drawes ageyne.

LG.HEAD: For betyn wounde or of staf smetynn.
LG.L: Tak garlyk hony & ȝolke of a ney.
And beet al to geder in a morter.
And it schal dryue out al þe venyme.
wt outen gret sore or any pynynge.

LG.HEAD: A drynke for a wounde to drawe out blod.
LG.L: Tak fenycle herbe Iohn & homlok rote.
And leues of betayne þe schal be bote.
wel soden to gedere in gode reed wyne.
This drynke schal clere the wounde ful fyne.
so þt þe seke man drynke other none.
Tille he may bothe ryde and gone.

LG.HEAD: ffor the pockes.
LG.L: Seynt Nichasy hadde a pok þt was nouȝt small.
And mekyl greuance he hadde wt all.
He prayde to gode þt hym dere bought.
Who so enterlyke hym be sought.
That he hym fro þe pokkes schude were.
If he on hym wretyn his name walde bere.

LG.HEAD: ffor þe bon ake.
LG.L: Who so is betyn & has bon ake
Bugile comferi and fenicle take.
Consoude betayne auance also.
Lauander tansey omounde þer to.
Thes greses wele drynke he may.
In gode old ale bothe nyght & day.

LG.HEAD: ffor the felon a medcyne.
LG.L: Take þe fairest of þe whete
And do it al togeder bete.
And menge wt mylk off womman mylde.
That has borne a knaue childe.
If a feloun wax full of bleches ouer alle.
Take plantayne & grynd it small.
wt þe Ious a noynte the felloun well
In plaister lay one þt other dele.

WASH., U.S.A. December 4, 1909.
